title: Ticket #2899: classad lex/parse uses up to 50% of the compute time for daemons
description:
Classads go over the wire using an unparse -> wire -> lex -> parse sequence. Lexing and parsing (and especially lexing) tend to be expensive operations.

Since sending classads around between daemons is a major activity in condor, I profiled a "busy" collector and verified that up to 50% of its computation is in lex/parse (and mostly lex, which is typical of lexers).

I believe that the lexer can be usefully streamlined without a total overhaul of the libraries. That change would be fairly localized, since the lexer and its output are not visible to most of the system. (In principle I also think the classad libs could be more generally redesigned for improved efficiency, at the expense of higher impact to the code).

Streamlining the lexer would positively impact all classad communication between condor daemons, and also improve performance of condor history parsing.
remarks:
2012-Mar-19 17:48:36 by eje:
Another option would be to alter the wire protocol for classads so that the internal expression tree is sent over, and reconstructed directly on the receiving end, which side-steps the need to do lexing and parsing.

This could also be localized, to the routines that to the put/get on classads. It would be a bit more development, kind of like a version of unparse that pushes internal expr tree nodes across the wire, and the inverse that reassembles them.

This has the potential to reduce the cycles by a lot more than just a lexer overhaul, although it also would not make any improvement to reading history file, which has to be lexed/parsed.

2012-Mar-20 12:56:58 by tannenba:
Yet another option, that may be very simple to implement, is to cache expression parse trees at the classad library level. The cache could just be a hashtable mapping strings to parse-tree counted-pointers. So if the classad library is about to parse the expression 
   Start = LoadAvg < 1.5
it would first do a simple hash lookup with they key being the un-parsed expression (aka just a string). So if the collector receives 1M ads with the same Start expression, it is only parsed once. This change would be localized, have a large impact, and would not need to change anything about the wire format (that is a good thing for backwards compatibility). Only possible complication is how new classads "nest" expressions to deal with nested ads etc, but I have not looked at the new classad code much - maybe it is not a concern.

I really think this is the way to go here.... it is something I've wanted to do for a long time. In fact, I was going to do it a couple years back, but decided against it because we were using old classads at the time... figured I'd wait until new classads were in place so I didn't have to make this change twice.

2012-Mar-20 12:58:27 by tannenba:
How is this related to the classad library caching work that Tim has been working on? (don't have the ticket num handy, Tim?)

2012-Mar-21 14:59:20 by eje:
FWIW: I hotrodded the lexer on an experimental branch. I got it to run 40% faster (without making any high-impact changes). It made condor_history 15% faster in my sandbox testing.

I'd want to do more local testing and run it thru batlab, etc, but it looks reasonable.

2012-May-01 11:40:44 by tstclair:
So ideally I think updating the ClassAdParser with the caching mechanism would yield massive gains. 

ClassAdParser::parseClassAd ()
{

...
if (!cache_hit(key, val, tree& ))
{
    parseExpression(tree&)
}

...
}

circumvent lexing if there is a cache hit on a string match.

That is all fine and dandy "in theory" but from what I see, there is no easy way to get "val" without lexing.. :-(.

2012-May-01 13:02:50 by eje:
In practice, I think a slightly simpler slant would work, and cover the large majority of cases for a major speedup. 

bool ClassAdParser::ParseExpression( const string &buffer, ExprTree *&tree, bool full ) {

    if (expr_cache.defined(buffer)) {
       tree = expr_cache[buffer];
       return;
    }

    // otherwise do the existing logic to get (tree)

    if (!tree_contains_assignment_op(tree)) {
        // I believe we can safely store any expr not involving assignment
        expr_cache[buffer] = tree;
    }
}
